Hacksaw

A critical hit sometimes causes an attack to deal increased damage to a pupil. However, I have the 2nd tier critical upgrade and a barely see any crits come in, let alone come in on a student that wouldn't have been knocked out without it anyways.

Personally, I'd go with MC (which I also have) because answering pupil questions is a helpful way of knocking them out sooner.

I should also probably start keeping notes on the costs to compare with people who don't have the skill, since I got the MC skill real early and have seen only a couple options without it, you know, to make sure it really is reducing the cost.
On july 9, 2013
TradeFederation

I would say the first skill is better. You get student questions fairly often, and it could be worth it to use your self control to lower their stupidity directly.


A critical hit is an old Dungeons and Dragons gameplay element where when you rolled the dice well, you got an extra effect. It now shows up in many different games. Here it is double damage when you use your abilities to remove ignorance and stupidity. I rarely see it, so I would guess its something like a 1-3% chance.


Since you don't know the odds of it happening, you don't know how much better the odds get, and you don't know which skills can critical, its a big unknown what you will actually get from this. On the plus side, its a passive skill, and adds to (i assume) most of your normal skills. Less active skills means less randomness in your main actions, which is a good thing to some extent.
On july 9, 2013
npfan

I would go with the first option. As mentioned before, it might be worth it to spend 1-2 SC to get rid of stupidity, and the first option makes it more cost effective. With the second option, the difference is very marginal, and you'll usually end up using actions where critical hits occur when those hits didn't need to be critical.

On july 10, 2013
Hacksaw

I think there are a few people on the boards here that would LOVE to have Counter Attack. But, in my opinion, since it's RNG whether or not a student will attack and then RNG again whether or not you'll get Counter Attack next turn, it's increased chance you won't be able to use it. IMO, if you have Good Memory as well, and/or are willing to spend 5 euro's on budget to unlock the chained action, then it'll be worth tempting the RNG gods, otherwise you could find it causing more harm than good.

Exercise looks like a delayed action Teach attack (which causes 2 damage to all students at a table immediately) except it may not be boostable with Twinoids (plus or minus Vitaboost). Unless it shows up in the last turn or two of the class, kind of makes it no harm done, and unless you left out notation where the students become untargetable, possible you can continue to help expediate the damage by still attacking them.

The way my classes typically run I'd find this level up option to be a complete dud, and would choose Exercise to make it less of a dud, or would look for the 5 euros to unlock the chained option in hopes it's something more useful.

On july 11, 2013
Hacksaw

I used to use Pay Attention to remove boredom from students (or Pop Quiz with Twinoid) and still do on occasion, but I've also unlocked Front of the Class which is very nice for removing all boredom from a student no matter how much it is, and there's also sponges (if you have the budget or can afford to pay real money for budget) and some pet abilities that help mitigate boredom, so I already have more than enough ways to handle it.

Solid Explenation, on the other hand, has been an invaluable skill for me since I picked it up on my first level up to help keep my SC up. Would have been many more classes I would have had to Relax a little instead of correcting papers or sharing the experience if I hadn't had the skill, so I'm definitely gaining a lot more from this one. Also remember that you gain +1 SC for every point of stupidity damage, even from bonus damage from twinoids and critical hits, so if your student has enough points, don't be afraid to pop that twinoid before giving the student a Solid Explenation

Edit: Should probably disclaimer I'm still guessing on the critical hits since they come up way too rarely to test.

Just a correction: i have sacrifice, and that isn't exactly what it does. I would word it as:
Sacrifice: Deals 3 [Stupidity] damage to the student. This skill bypasses boredom. For every point of boredom bypassed in this way, you lose 1 SC.

It's not really that good once you know how i really works, especially since I typically use Sacrifice on a student with no boredom instead (to take 0 damage), I'd take educational flick.

Tough choice here:

Choose a new skill:

Interesting Anecdote

Each pupil at the targeted table loses 2 Boredom/Stupidity. This skill bypasses their boredom.
(It's an error to use the red/white icon when the ability can never do Boredom damage, but whatever. That error is repeated in many other skills.)

Individual Work

The targeted pupil will work on their own until the end of the lesson. They lose 1 Boredom/Stupidity per turn and can no longer be targeted.

Wake Up You Lot

All pupils at tables in the targeted row become 'attentive'.

Is Interesting Anecdote written correctly? As in, is it really a table action and does the ability bypass Boredom as stated?

For Individual Work, can the student still be targeted by other student's actions? And do they still take actions of their own? I'd think that you might count the Boredom/Stupidity of the student and think you've got him beaten, and then find that he takes a "bored" action and adds a Boredom, or is on the receiving end of a "tacks" action and gains a Stupidity, therefore screwing up your calculation.

Is Wake Up You Lot really a row action?

It's sad that there are so many poorly worded or just outright wrong descriptions of abilities that I feel the need to check with people who may have actually used them before I pick one...

Okay, some news on Maths Bumps.

Wow, tough choice. For me, I would first put Uber Concentration at the bottom of the list. Yes, it's better than Pay Attention!, but not much.

Let's Get Serious is a bit more interesting because it can bypass . However, this skill will affect on average two students since three-seat tables are quite rare. This would certainly be good to take out a student(s) with 3 or less , some amount of , and a negative status.

If I had to choose between those two, I would side with Brainwash since I can do more damage on average while Let's Get Serious is really good only on certain circumstances.

ps : some one explain the life transfrer plz? o.o
On july 31, 2013
ChooJeremy

Life transfer basically means that at the end of the next 3 turns, you gain +1SC for every non-defeated pupil at the table.

For example, there's a table with 2 seats. One student is sitting there and you use life transfer on him.
End of turn: +1SC (1 student).
On the next turn, you move a student to that table
End of turn: +2SC (2 students at table)
On the next turn, you KO the student that you moved there.
End of turn: +1SC (1 student at table, defeated students do not count).

Personally, I'd go with life transfer. I kinda liked having more ways to increase my SC, although I know others will disagree

On august 1, 2013
Hacksaw

From what I've heard I don't think Psych Record is completely useless, but it does require at least level 2 (that's two level ups) to glean enough useful information out of it, and probably Extra Class level 1 at least (another level up) to increase your class choices to truly optimize the information gleaned.

Also, to break it down a little.
3 Farrier costs 100 and provides a total 45 SC, or 0.45 SC per 1
With EB1 you save 5, giving you effectively 2.25 SC free, so if you're buying the 3-pack then Upgraded self Control 1 is better.

10 Farrier costs 250 and provides a total 150 SC, or 0.6 SC per 1
With EB1 you save 13, giving you effectively 7.8 SC for free, so if you're buying the 10-pack then Experienced Buyer 1 is better.

On august 11, 2013
TradeFederation
coroI feel that unless you really really like the score bonus from using Helping Hand, you should go with a passive skill for your first grade change

I personally heavily favor passive choices for permanent choices. The thing is that attacks 'clutter up' your choices, and make it less likely to get what you need for any particular situation for the rest of your Teacher Story days. If you have to take a bad passive at a level up, it really has little negative effect, except that you could possibly have had something better, but if you have to take a useless attack, it hurts your class actions directly.


Of the ones mentioned, Good memory is just insanely better than any other choice. This was my first permanent, and I'd never want to go back to not having it. Other passives I like are Rigged Clock and Upgraded Healing Potion. Having extra turns just makes everything in the game easier, no matter if you are waiting for a good attack, using damage over time attacks, picking up student items, or just getting +1 XP and or cheaper timer skipping every class. Using Ferriers is likewise the simplest and fastest way to maintain your SC without wasting attacks, so why not make them a lot better on a permanent basis.


For active attacks, I would not want to take any meh, or just ok attacks as permanents, its better to have them as choices when you re-level up, so you have less chances of having to take a REALLY bad attack, do to all the choices being poor. But from what I have seen, Burst of Knowledge, Brainwash, and Exercise do the most 'splash damage', and would almost always be as good or better than any of the starter attacks. Just below those 3 would be Individual Study. Its more situational (useless on the last turn), but its side effect of immediately neutralizing about half of the negative statuses a student might have, in addition to beating a student make it effective in many situations.
On august 11, 2013
TradeFederation
npfanI would go with Let's Get Serious. You could remove as much as 9 and could immediately get rid of students with a negative status and 3 or less .

I far prefer this choice as well, just because Life Transfer is not really an 'attack', but more like an improved Solace. It does get you SC, but you have to not only miss an attack, but you also have to avoid taking out those students for 3 additional turns (assuming you HAVE three more turns, and you still have a table of 2 or 3 you don't need to take out fast) , if you can. IMO, since you can earn enough budget 'naturally' to buy the Ferriers you need, I'd much rather just 'win' faster (or be more sure to have the turns I need to win) and just pop a Ferrier, than delay my victory to try to manipulate the class to recover SC through this method.


I have had Life Transfer both grades I have played, and I just find it not usefull and cluttering up my attack options most of the time it comes up, as I usually just want to make student damaging attacks most of the time.

BTW: Upgraded Crit has been dogged on these forums, but it really pays off on attacks like Exercise and Academic Bomb, where there are lots of pupils taking damage. I usually see a crit about every second mass attack, and it is occasionally on more than one pupil. Here you're not counting on a set amount of damage to take out a pupil, so the crit damage is a nice bonus instead of a wasted bonus.

Hacksaw
Kowasaci1I. DO. NOT. EXIST.

Joking aside, the pains of being the last post on the page, I guess.

IMO, if you're willing and/or able to use Twinoids on a regular basis (either freely because you can afford to, be it with budget earned or because you're willing to drop real cash on this game), or even if you use sparingly what few you're able to get for free (either from friends, side missions or earned-only budget), the Vitaboost ups their potency by making them apply a reduced bonus for another round. Often times I can use the +2 to knock out one student and then I got the +1 next round to help me knock out another student that would have otherwise needed two turns to defeat.

If you're one of those people who barely, if ever, even touches Twinoids or Sponges, then you probably won't get any use out of the Vitaboost and will have a better chance of seeing a benefit form the Fear.

Front of the Class!

Very useful when removing early on in the game and can do 10 damage with Big Brain, but can be annoying when it pops up later on. But in most situations it is more powerful that Pop Quiz.

Brainwash
An improvement on an already very good skill. Does huge damage, especially when combined with Big Brain or Twinoid.

Interesting Anecdote
Somewhat good. Can cause a double- in some cases, but regularly doing so will most likely use lots of Twinoids. It is not very powerful. A more useful skill would be Let's Get Serious, especially in a class with Gossip-type and Clown-type pupils.

I'm leanind towards Brainwash.

On august 20, 2013
Kompera

Upgraded Self Control is handy if you have Upgraded Healing Potion. At least for the first few levels. At Grade 3 Level 1 I had 20 SC. Upgraded Healing Potion heals 20 SC. So I always lost some of the benefit, especially as I don't ever want to risk a meltdown and hold off on drinking a Farrier until I'm at <4 SC.


Upgraded Critical Hit is very nice for mass effects, such as Exercise or Academic bomb. For those effects you aren't usually counting on the damage to beat a student, you're just looking to do a lot of damage to the class as a whole. So having UCH proc is a nice amount of bonus damage. And happens fairly frequently, as well.

So they are both conditional on other abilities to really shine.

And randomly not taking damage is nice.

TradeFederation

Both are situational attacks, and good in their own ways at different times in the class. Hypnotism does more indirect damage right away, although its much less useful later in the class when no one is bored. The Flick is always weak, and all but useless on the first few turns, but it is also a game-changing attack, if you can micromanage your student stupidity well, as it can complete missions in less total classes than would normally be possible (you will want to choose the fewer students need this grade missions with this, so you can more easily boost the few students that need the grade)

On august 25, 2013
Hacksaw

Base cost of items:
Farrier: 3 for 100 OR 10 for 250
Sponge: 3 for 50 OR 10 for 120
Twinoid: 3 for 60 OR 10 for 150

Experienced Buyer LV 1:
Farrier: 3 for 95 OR 10 for 237
Sponge: 3 for 47 OR 10 for 114
Twinoid: 3 for 57 OR 10 for 142

Now that you can see what the cost reduction will be for all purchases, the question comes down to how much to you purchase items? If you're one of the people who (almost) never uses sponges or twinoids, you'll get far less use out of EB1.

Conversely, a 10-pack of Farrier provides 150 SC for the cost of 250 , giving an average 0.6SC/1. If you have no qualms chugging Farrier when your SC is low, then that's likely a steady expenditure of for , and a 13 savings equates to 7.8 free SC overall (per 10-pack).

So unless you're one of those players who welcomes nervous breakdowns with open arms, and goes on regular sick leave to recover SC, you'll probably gain more out of EB1, even if you're only using it to buy a steady supply of Farrier.

If the targeted pupil has just inflicted damage on you
1. They have to inflict damage on you.
2. It's *only* the damage they JUST did. Not the cumulative damage.
3. The damage you suffer is already there. You don't get it back.

On september 6, 2013
Hacksaw

I was afraid I might have offended you, but then you asked
ShuDog
Whereas in that case, wouldn't Exercise just take care of the one student?.
which makes me think you don't know that the description for Exercise is inaccurate. Exercise hits ALL students in the classroom, no matter which desk, table, column or row they're sitting in. ALL students in the classroom (except those under the effects of Individual Work or untargetable via a critical status) are hit by Exercise (students not in the room because they are late, went to the bathroom, or are a pupil sent by a friend but it's still the first turn in the class they arrive are also not effected).

The only other thing is as Coro said, it takes two turns to reach full effect, so if all your students are in the same row (or it's the last turn or two), then Burst of Knowledge is definitely faster.

On september 6, 2013
mogman

Shudog... Exercise works on all students in the class, not just the targeted table. It's description has been misworded. Much better than BoK.

Just making sure you actually know that as you are making it sound worse than it is.

On september 20, 2013
Kompera

Upgraded Self Control has a limited but important use. If you have Upgraded Healing Potion, when you advance a Grade you'll find that the 20 SC the Ferrier gives you matches your SC pool. And you won't want to gamble on a meltdown, so you'll find yourself drinking Ferrier and losing some of the potential SC since the +20 on top of whatever you have will lose you the 'whatever you have' as overflow.

i.e. If you go down to 7 SC and drink an Upgraded Healing Potion, you'll only regain 13 SC instead of 20, since your SC pool is capped at 20. So you've essentially 'lost' 7 potential SC, since any future damage takes away from the 20 SC pool instead of the 27 SC pool you might have had with the various Upgraded Self Control skills.

This can be true for a couple of levels into the Grade, depending on your willingness to gamble on a meltdown.

It's a marginal case, to be sure.

This is a bit of a late reply, you've probably already made your selection. I wanted to point out that unless it has changed with the recent updates, Sacrifice is 3 points to all pupils at a table, not just the targeted pupil. Which makes it a direct upgrade to Teach, with the added mechanic of potentially bypassing at a cost in SC. The SC loss could be worth it to you or not, but I like the ability Wisdom Curveball which similarly bypasses even though it does not cost SC to do so.

Brainwash is also a direct upgrade to Teach Harder.

I'm not sure I see what's not to like about a 3 point attack to a table or a row.

Advanced Traineeship is a solid improvement of the basic skill Teach.

Individual Work is useful to take out a student with a lot of , as long as you're fortunate enough to get it early, which I usually have been. Stick the student on a single, out-of-the-way table, if you can, and hit them with Individual Work. They'll slowly lose points as you deal with the rest of the class--if you have the time left on the clock, it's a skill which essentially does damage equal to the number of the student has.

Individual Work is also useful if you have a really annoying student you want to take out of commission and can't knock out immediately using other skills. A student doing Individual Work can't attack you or his/her classmates.

A couple things to note with Individual Work, though, is that the student will *not* lose a point on the final turn, so you only want to apply it to a student you want to defeat if they have one less than there are turns left. Also, if you defeat all other available students, the student under Individual Work will come out of it and you'll have to defeat them normally. And finally, annoyingly, the order for students coming available from effects is Individual Work students first, then any KO'ed, Asleep, etc. students.

On september 26, 2013
Kompera
45424The Individual Work / Exercise not dealing damage on the last turn glitch may have been fixed in the update. Can someone check it out?

It's not a glitch. Direct damage you select is applied immediately. Indirect damage which is applied during the pupils' turn is applied in the pupils' turn.

The check for completion of a class is handled after the players turn. This means that any ongoing effects are handled after player effects such as Individual Work, Exercise, or Academic Bomb. This is easily verified by watching the application of any of these effects during the pupils' turn following the players' selection of this skill.

Documentary. You'll learn to count Boredom points and value your existing skills differently.
(e.g. If a student has 53 before you use Documentary, using Pop Quiz on this student only does 2 damage since the 2 is guaranteed to be removed sooner or later unless Documentary is never offered, while Wisdom Curveball also does 2 damage.)

[1306060]

While I've never had Trick Question, so I can't directly speak to its usefulness or lack thereof, Documentary gets an overall "meh" from me. Bottom line: They are all good skills. Not a runt in the litter.

Pick the one which best matches your current skills and pupils for this Grade*, or if you think you'd like to keep one of them permanently, pick that one and advance it when you go up a Grade.



* I had Let's get serious a couple Grades ago and while 3 damage to a table is very nice, I rarely got the use out of the special ability. Now I have it again and I'm almost always getting the 3 bypassing to at least one pupil at the table. Pupils change with each Grade, and skills can be more or less effective depending on the batch of pupils you've got in a given Grade.

Leapfrog
GhostMaths Bumps deals no damage to the student it's used on. As for the assigning of "Attentive" status, it's pure random, has a chance to target the same pupil multiple times, and has a chance to target pupils already KO'ed. On top of that, can't guarantee any student targeted won't be one that couldn't have been defeated without the status.

In my experience, Maths bump has always targeted the correct amount of individual students, and hasn't doubled up on the same one. I'm tempted to suggest that it's been fixed or upgraded, but I haven't used it nearly enough to be able to make a definitive statement about it.


Still, I think it's worth considering that Maths Bump also has the added utility of temporarily putting a stop to a troublesome student. I don't know which statuses KO will knock out and which it won't, but I just used it against a student using the voodoo doll ability and it wiped the negative status off in addition to temporarily shutting him up.


So, depending on the situation, it can be a good way to deal with negative statuses, in a way that actually translates to damage against other students, rather than just knocking off a boredom point or two.


I'm not offering a conclusion as to whether this makes it a worthwhile pick versus various other skills (I've never had Big Clean Up, for example), but I think its utility should be considered.

Right now I'm sitting on UR3, and it has a pretty good trigger rate. Not as often as I'd like against high damage attacks, but I'm seeing at least 1-2 resists a class easy, more if I get a lot of DOT effects.

Individual Work
The targeted pupil will work on their own until the end of the lesson. They lose 1 per turn and can no longer be targeted.

Counter Attack
If the targeted pupil has just inflicted damage on you, you inflict double the damage you sustained on them.

Trick Question
The targeted pupil loses 4 . If they are defeated, the other pupils at the table become 'Attentive'.

On december 13, 2013
Kompera

k0l3It's just useless as preparation for flicker or helping hand, but otherwise it's excellent.If you're careful and lucky, it doesn't have to be. While I typically target a pupil with Individual Work who can be defeated by that one attack (i.e. = (Turns_remaining -1)), if I get it in the middle or late game I can target a pupil to be 'nibbled away' at while I defeat the remaining pupils. This is great for high pupils who will be brought into a reasonable attack range with just a single attack, or to temporarily get rid of a pupil with high damaging attacks or who has a negative effect you'd like to clear.

One the rest of the class is beaten IW breaks and the pupil is again able to be targeted. I imagine it would take luck as well as skill to set the pupil up for an EF or a HH, but it can be done.

45424

The only negative statuses that take you longer to finish a lesson are Asleep (Rip Van Winkle specific), Sulking (randomly from Chatting), Head in the clouds (Dreamer specific) and Totally Lost (Less-than-gifted, Curious and randomly from Chatting). None of them are mass effects.

Others don't hinder lesson completion and can be ignored.

On january 9, 2014
45424
goatwhat do u mean teaching log

This.
It basically keeps track of any action in the class, so you'll know which skill is impossible to be offered on the next turn(s) and which student(s) are unlikely to attack again (students' signature attacks have cooldowns too - mostly once per class), so that you can plan ahead.

norby89
goathey if someone sends me a pupil will it go away after i complete the mission? cuz pupils are annoying i cant beat the class

Pupils are great, they help you finish a mission faster, they also add +1 to the total number of turns and +1 to the classes you have to finish a mission. The only time they're unhelpful is when you have a minimum score or an "x" repeating students mission and the pupil starts with a very low score.

And yes a pupil goes away once you finish a mission.

On january 24, 2014
norby89
goatthank goondess they disappear after the mission though, wait but are they helpful in the sense that if you beat the mission you get something extra?

If you had Psych Record maxed out then you'd notice that most "X Pupils at YY" missions have X-1 number of pupils with good scores and the rest with very low scores, forcing you to either bring a very stupid student's score up (which might cost you the mission) or ask for help from a friend. Most of the time a friend's pupil will have a high score that will help you finish a mission in 2-3 turns that otherwise would have taken 5-6 turns.

They don't help in minimum score missions directly but they extend the number of classes by 1 each which in turn can be helpful.
